description: From Old French professer, and its source, the participle stem of Latin profitērī, from pro- + fatērī (“to confess, acknowledge”).

verbs.description: profess (third-person singular simple present professes, present participle professing, simple past and past participle professed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, chiefly passive) To administer the vows of a religious order to (someone); to admit to a religious order. [from 14th c.]
examples: This swayed the balance decisively in Mary's favour, and she was professed on 8 September 1578.

entries.meaning: (reflexive) To declare oneself (to be something). [from 16th c.]
(transitive, intransitive) To declare; to assert, affirm. [from 16th c.]
(transitive) To make a claim (to be something); to lay claim to (a given quality, feeling etc.), often with connotations of insincerity. [from 16th c.]
(transitive) To declare one's adherence to (a religion, deity, principle etc.). [from 16th c.]
examples: The remainder of the population, about two-thirds, belongs to the Mongolian race and professes Buddhism.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To work as a professor of; to teach. [from 16th c.]
(transitive, now rare) To claim to have knowledge or understanding of (a given area of interest, subject matter). [from 16th c.]
